plants.name: Lilium bulbiferum
plants.description: A striking perennial lily native to Europe known for its vibrant orange flowers with red spots. It typically grows in meadows and hillsides and attracts butterflies and bees during summer.
plants.funFact: The Orange Lily's bulbils on its stem allow it to propagate vegetatively, which is quite rare among lilies.

plants.name: Rosa chinensis
plants.description: A significant rose species cultivated worldwide, blooming multiple times during warm months. It has been fundamental in breeding the modern hybrid tea roses.
plants.location: Native to China, cultivated worldwide in temperate and subtropical areas
plants.funFact: China Roses are remontant, meaning they can bloom several times in a season, including mid-summer.

plants.name: Protea cynaroides
plants.description: The national flower of South Africa, notable for its enormous flower heads resembling artichokes. It thrives in Mediterranean-type climates and blooms during southern hemisphere winter to spring but can also bloom sporadically through July in some areas.
plants.funFact: The King Protea's flower head is actually a collection of many small flowers, surrounded by colorful bracts.

plants.name: Lupinus polyphyllus
plants.description: This ornamental and wildflower species is native to western North America and commonly seen blooming in meadows and hills during midsummer, attractive to pollinators.
plants.funFact: Lupines can fix nitrogen in the soil through their root nodules, improving soil fertility.
